title: Historical stock splits and corporate actions related to Tupperware Brands Corp

content.text: Tupperware Brands Corp had its initial public offering (IPO) in 1966, becoming a publicly traded company.
Tupperware Brands Corp announced a 2-for-1 stock split in 1971. This split increased the number of shares outstanding while reducing their individual value.
Tupperware Brands Corp implemented another 2-for-1 stock split in 1973. This split aimed to lower the stock price and make it more accessible to investors.
Tupperware Brands Corp spun off its subsidiary, Tupperware Corporation, as an independent company in 1996. This move allowed each company to focus on its specific market and operations.
Tupperware Brands Corp executed a 2-for-1 stock split in 2001. This was done to adjust the stock price and potentially attract more investors.
Tupperware Brands Corp acquired BeautiControl, a direct selling beauty and skincare company, in 2006. This acquisition expanded Tupperware's product offering and market presence.
Tupperware Brands Corp announced a 2-for-1 stock split in 2011. This split aimed to maintain a reasonable stock price and enhance trading liquidity.

In 2020, Tupperware Brands Corp made the decision to delist its stock from the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) and move to the OTC (Over-the-Counter) Market. This transition allowed for more flexibility and cost savings.
